page.title: Nominal Phrases - Case
page.introduction:
As discussed in
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, languages may have no case system, or they may follow a nominative-accusative system, an ergative-absolutive system, or have split ergativity, which involves both case systems in certain grammatical conditions.
Some languages mark case on nouns or nominal phrases as well as pronouns, while others only show case in the pronouns, if they mark case at all.
There are more cases to consider beyond that of the subject and object, also. These may include ablative case for a source or origin, genitive case for kinds or possessors, dative case for indirect objects, instrumental case for means or instruments, locative case for locations, vocative case for direct address, and oblique case is sometimes used for the minor grammatical relations.
These additional cases are usually marked with case markers on the phrases themselves in languages which normally mark case on nouns or nominal phrases as well as pronouns. For languages without any case marking and those which only show case in the pronouns, these additional grammatical relations are normally expressed via prepositional or postpositional phrases.

In the grammar rules generated by this starter kit, languages which have case marking on nouns or nominal phrases will have all of the grammatical relations expressed as DPs, whereas those languages which only show case distinctions in the pronouns or not at all, will have DPs for subjects and objects but PPs for all other grammatical relations.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have case markers on nouns or nominal phrases?
radioGroup.radio: No, there is no marking on nouns or nominal phrases. Only the pronoun systems indicate the case distinctions
Yes, nouns or nominal phrases carry case marking as well as pronouns

form.prompt:
In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language does not have any case distinctions. Therefore, the minor grammatical relations will normally be expressed by prepositional or postpositional phrases, rather than by nominal phrases.

Since your language does not mark any case distinctions on nouns or nominal phrases, the minor grammatical relations will normally be expressed by prepositional or postpositional phrases, rather than by nominal phrases. The case distinctions in the pronouns will be delineated in
Pronouns.

radioGroup.prompt: Is there a default (unmarked) case for your language?
radioGroup.radio: No, all the case markers are overt (some null allomorphs are OK)
Yes, nominative case is completely unmarked, but the others are overt (some null allomorphs are OK)

radioGroup.prompt: Is the case marker written as a separate word?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No, it attaches to another word in the nominal phrase

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the case marker word occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the case marker words appear on either side of the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

form.instruction: In the lexicon, mark those case markers which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the case marker attach to the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: To the beginning of the initial word in the nominal phrase
To the end of the final word in the nominal phrase
Some attach to the beginning of the initial word and some attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase
As a prefix to the head noun
As a suffix to the head noun
Some are prefixes and some are suffixes which attach to the head noun

radioGroup.prompt: Which case is used to mark the possessorsfor the possessive pronouns in your language?
radioGroup.radio: Ergative, the same as the subjects of transitive verbs
Absolutive, the same as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs
Genitive, distinct for possessors

radioGroup.prompt: Which case is used to mark the possessorsfor the possessive pronouns in the parts of your language that display split ergativity?
radioGroup.radio: Ergative, the same as the subjects of transitive verbs
Absolutive, the same as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs
Genitive, the same as in the nominative-accusative constructions

form.prompt: For all of the following text boxes, enter the case marker with a hyphen on the appropriate side to indicate which side it attaches on. Ifif there is more than one marker for a particiular case, enter each on a separate line. If your language does not use a particular case, simply leave that text box empty.
Key the case marker your language uses for nominative case to express the subject (at least for Agents):
Key the case marker your language uses for accusative case to express the direct object and other uses:
Key the case marker your language uses for ergative case to express the subject of transitive verbs (at least for Agents):
Key the case marker your language uses for ergative case to express the subject of transitive verbs (at least for Agents) in the parts of your language that display split ergativity:
Key the case marker your language uses for absolutive case to express the subject of intransitive verbs (at least for Agents) and the direct object of transitive verbs:

Key the case marker your language uses for absolutive case to express the subject of intransitive verbs (at least for Agents) and the direct object of transitive verbs in the parts of your language that display split ergativity:
Key the case marker your language uses for genitive case to express possession:
Key the case marker your language uses for dative case to express the indirect object and possibly the subject of verbs with Experiencer subjects:
Key the case marker your language uses for ablative case to express source or origin:
Key the case marker your language uses for instrumental case to express the instrument, means or agency:
Key the case marker your language uses for locative case to express the location:
Key the case marker your language uses for vocative case to express a direct address:
Key the case marker your language uses for oblique case to express a general minor grammatical relation:
Key any other specific case markers your language uses to express a minor grammatical relation:
form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the appropriate case feature to these affixes: nominative, accusative, ergative, absolutive, genitive, dative, ablative, instrumental, locative, vocative or oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature accusative.or.dative instead of simply accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature absolutive.or.dative instead of simply absolutive for this case marker.

In the lexicon, add the appropriate case feature to these proclitics: case_prefix_nominative, case_prefix_accusative, case_prefix_ergative, case_prefix_absolutive, case_prefix_genitive, case_prefix_dative, case_prefix_ablative, case_prefix_instrumental, case_prefix_locative, case_prefix_vocative or case_prefix_oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_prefix_accusative.or.dative instead of simply case_prefix_accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_prefix_absolutive.or.dative instead of simply case_prefix_absolutive for this case marker.

In the lexicon, add the appropriate case feature to these enclitics: case_suffix_nominative, case_suffix_accusative, case_suffix_ergative, case_suffix_absolutive, case_suffix_genitive, case_suffix_dative, case_suffix_ablative, case_suffix_instrumental, case_suffix_locative, case_suffix_vocative or case_suffix_oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_suffix_accusative.or.dative instead of simply case_suffix_accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_suffix_absolutive.or.dative instead of simply case_suffix_absolutive for this case marker.

In the lexicon, add the appropriate case feature to the proclitics: case_prefix_nominative, case_prefix_accusative, case_prefix_ergative, case_prefix_absolutive, case_prefix_genitive, case_prefix_dative, case_prefix_ablative, case_prefix_instrumental, case_prefix_locative, case_prefix_vocative or case_prefix_oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_prefix_accusative.or.dative instead of simply case_prefix_accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_prefix_absolutive.or.dative instead of simply case_prefix_absolutive for this case marker. Add the appropriate case feature to the enclitics: case_suffix_nominative, case_suffix_accusative, case_suffix_ergative, case_suffix_absolutive, case_suffix_genitive, case_suffix_dative, case_suffix_ablative, case_suffix_instrumental, case_suffix_locative, case_suffix_vocative or case_suffix_oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_suffix_accusative.or.dative instead of simply case_suffix_accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature case_suffix_absolutive.or.dative instead of simply case_suffix_absolutive for this case marker.

In the lexicon, if the case words do not already have the category Case, add the feature makeCase to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. (If a particular entry can also be used as another syntactic category, make a separate lexical entry for each use.) Also, add the appropriate case feature to these case words: nominative, accusative, ergative, absolutive, genitive, dative, ablative, instrumental, locative, vocative or oblique. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature accusative.or.dative instead of simply accusative for this case marker. Since your language uses the normal object case for Experiencer subjects, use the feature absolutive.or.dative instead of simply absolutive for this case marker.
